questions.question: What happens to BIOS settings if the CMOS battery fails?
options: Settings are saved to the hard drive
questions.explanation: BIOS information is maintained through the CMOS battery. If the battery no longer provides power, configuration settings may be lost.

questions.question: Which RAID level provides data striping without redundancy?
questions.explanation: RAID 0 provides data striping across multiple disks for improved performance but offers no redundancy or fault tolerance.

questions.question: What is the main advantage of UEFI over traditional BIOS?
options: Support for larger boot drives and secure boot
questions.explanation: UEFI supports larger boot drives (over 2TB), secure boot, faster startup, and can run on both 32-bit and 64-bit systems.

questions.question: What does CPU virtualization enable?
options: A single processor to act as multiple processors
questions.explanation: CPU virtualization is a hardware feature that enables a single processor to act as multiple processors, allowing multiple VMs to run in parallel.

questions.question: Which three features can be configured in BIOS to secure a computer?
questions.explanation: BIOS security features include passwords, drive encryption settings, and TPM (Trusted Platform Module) configuration.

questions.question: What is overclocking?
options: Running the CPU at lower speeds to save power
Increasing the CPU clock speed beyond manufacturer specifications
Adding more RAM to the system
questions.explanation: Overclocking is increasing the CPU clock speed beyond manufacturer specifications to make the computer run faster, but it generates more heat.

questions.question: Which two considerations are most important when building a workstation for multiple VMs?
options: Large amounts of RAM and powerful CPU
questions.explanation: Virtual machines require substantial RAM and CPU processing power as each VM needs its own allocated resources.

questions.question: What indicates a hardware failure during POST?
questions.explanation: During POST, the BIOS uses beep codes (patterns of beeps) to indicate specific hardware failures when the system cannot display error messages.

questions.question: What is a multicore processor?
options: Multiple separate CPUs on the motherboard
A CPU that can run multiple operating systems
Two or more processors on the same integrated circuit
A processor with multiple cache levels
questions.explanation: Multicore processors have two or more processor cores on the same integrated circuit, allowing parallel processing.

questions.question: After a power outage, a server displays 'RAID not found'. What is a possible cause?
options: RAID controller not receiving power or failed
questions.explanation: RAID not found errors can be caused by the RAID controller not receiving power, controller failure, or incorrect BIOS settings.

questions.question: Which RAID level requires a minimum of 3 drives and provides redundancy?
questions.explanation: RAID 5 requires a minimum of 3 drives and provides data striping with distributed parity for redundancy.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Secure Boot in UEFI?
options: Ensure only trusted operating systems can boot
questions.explanation: Secure Boot ensures that devices will only boot a trusted operating system by verifying digital signatures.

questions.question: Which power state allows a computer to return to work quickly while consuming almost no power?
questions.explanation: S3 (Sleep/Standby) maintains RAM contents while most components are powered down, allowing quick resume with minimal power consumption.

questions.question: What technology allows the CPU to adjust its clock speed based on workload?
questions.explanation: Turbo Boost (Intel) and Turbo Core (AMD) dynamically increase CPU clock speed when needed for demanding tasks.

questions.question: Which component determines the maximum amount of RAM a system can support?
questions.explanation: The motherboard chipset determines the maximum RAM capacity, types supported, and number of memory slots available.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the TPM (Trusted Platform Module)?
options: Store encryption keys and passwords securely
questions.explanation: TPM is a hardware security chip that stores encryption keys, passwords, and digital certificates securely.

questions.question: Which RAID level provides mirroring for redundancy?
questions.explanation: RAID 1 provides mirroring, where data is duplicated on two drives for redundancy and fault tolerance.

questions.question: What happens in ACPI power state S4?
options: RAM contents saved to disk, system powered off
questions.explanation: S4 (Hibernate) saves RAM contents to disk and powers off the system, allowing full state restoration on next boot.

questions.question: Which technology allows a single physical CPU core to handle two threads simultaneously?
questions.explanation: Hyper-Threading (Intel) and Simultaneous Multithreading (AMD) allow a single CPU core to process two threads simultaneously.

questions.question: What is required to enter UEFI/BIOS setup on most modern systems?
options: Pressing a specific key during POST (like F2, Del, or Esc)
questions.explanation: Accessing UEFI/BIOS typically requires pressing a specific key (F2, Delete, Esc, etc.) during the POST process.

questions.question: Which bus connects the CPU to high-speed components like RAM and graphics cards?
questions.explanation: The Front Side Bus (FSB) or modern equivalents connect the CPU to high-speed components like RAM and the graphics card slot.

questions.question: What is the main disadvantage of RAID 0?
options: No fault tolerance - if one drive fails, all data is lost
questions.explanation: RAID 0 provides no redundancy - if any drive in the array fails, all data across all drives is lost.

questions.question: Which feature must be enabled in BIOS/UEFI to run virtual machines efficiently?
questions.explanation: Hardware virtualization extensions (Intel VT-x or AMD-V) must be enabled in BIOS/UEFI for efficient VM performance.

questions.question: What is the maximum partition size supported by MBR?
questions.explanation: MBR (Master Boot Record) supports a maximum partition size of 2TB, while GPT supports much larger partitions.

questions.question: Which component is responsible for controlling data flow between CPU, RAM, and peripheral devices?
questions.explanation: The chipset manages data flow between the CPU, memory, and peripheral devices on the motherboard.

questions.question: What type of cooling is recommended for overclocked CPUs?
questions.explanation: Overclocked CPUs generate significantly more heat and require high-performance air coolers or liquid cooling solutions.

questions.question: Which RAID level combines mirroring and striping?
questions.explanation: RAID 10 (or 1+0) combines RAID 1 mirroring with RAID 0 striping for both performance and redundancy.

questions.question: What is the purpose of CPU cache?
options: Provide fast access to frequently used data
questions.explanation: CPU cache provides extremely fast access to frequently used data and instructions, reducing memory access latency.

questions.question: Which boot mode is required for drives larger than 2TB?
questions.explanation: UEFI boot mode with GPT (GUID Partition Table) is required to boot from drives larger than 2TB.

questions.question: What does enabling XMP/DOCP in BIOS do?
options: Apply RAM manufacturer's tested overclocking profiles
questions.explanation: XMP (Intel) and DOCP (AMD) enable pre-tested RAM overclocking profiles for optimal memory performance.

questions.question: Which technology provides out-of-band management for servers?
questions.explanation: IPMI, iLO (HP), and iDRAC (Dell) provide out-of-band management, allowing remote access even when the OS is down.

questions.question: What happens when you clear CMOS?
options: BIOS settings return to factory defaults
questions.explanation: Clearing CMOS resets all BIOS/UEFI settings to factory defaults, useful for troubleshooting configuration issues.

questions.question: Which CPU feature helps prevent malicious code execution?
questions.explanation: The NX bit (No-Execute bit) marks memory pages as non-executable, preventing malicious code from running in data areas.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of drives required for RAID 10?
questions.explanation: RAID 10 requires a minimum of 4 drives - pairs of drives are mirrored, then the mirrors are striped.

questions.question: Which voltage is primarily used by modern DDR4 RAM?
questions.explanation: DDR4 RAM operates at 1.2V standard voltage, lower than DDR3's 1.5V, improving power efficiency.

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of Intel's hybrid architecture in 12th/13th generation processors?
options: Efficient combination of performance and efficiency cores
questions.explanation: Intel's hybrid architecture combines high-performance P-cores for demanding tasks with efficient E-cores for background processes, optimizing both performance and power consumption.

questions.question: Which RAID level provides the best performance for a database server requiring both speed and fault tolerance?
questions.explanation: RAID 10 combines striping (RAID 0) for performance with mirroring (RAID 1) for redundancy, providing excellent read/write performance and fault tolerance suitable for database servers.

questions.question: What is the maximum theoretical PCIe 5.0 x16 bandwidth?
questions.explanation: PCIe 5.0 provides 4 GB/s per lane. A x16 slot delivers 64 GB/s of theoretical bandwidth (4 GB/s × 16 lanes), double that of PCIe 4.0.

questions.question: Which CPU cache level has the lowest latency but smallest capacity?
questions.explanation: L1 cache is the fastest but smallest cache level, typically 32-64KB per core with 1-2 cycle latency. Each level increases in size but adds latency.

questions.question: What is the primary security benefit of TPM 2.0 over TPM 1.2?
questions.explanation: TPM 2.0 supports modern cryptographic algorithms (SHA-256, AES, RSA 2048), algorithm agility, and enhanced authorization policies compared to TPM 1.2's limited algorithm support.

questions.question: Which NVMe feature significantly improves performance in enterprise environments?
questions.explanation: NVMe supports up to 65,536 outstanding commands across multiple queues, compared to AHCI/SATA's single queue with 32 commands, dramatically improving concurrent I/O performance.

questions.question: What is the main advantage of AMD's chiplet architecture?
options: Better yields and scalability across product lines
questions.explanation: AMD's chiplet design allows better manufacturing yields (smaller dies have fewer defects) and easy scalability from 4-core to 64-core processors using the same core design.

questions.question: Which UEFI setting is essential for Windows 11 installation on modern systems?
questions.explanation: Windows 11 requires UEFI mode with Secure Boot enabled and TPM 2.0 for security features. Legacy BIOS mode is not supported for Windows 11 installation.

questions.question: What causes the 'CPU over temperature' warning in BIOS?
options: CPU thermal sensors detecting unsafe temperatures
questions.explanation: Modern CPUs have built-in thermal sensors that trigger warnings when junction temperatures exceed safe thresholds (typically 90-100°C), preventing permanent damage.

questions.question: Which memory configuration provides the best performance on modern dual-channel systems?
questions.explanation: For dual-channel operation, install matched memory modules in slots 2 and 4 (or as indicated by motherboard manual) to enable dual-channel mode for optimal bandwidth.

questions.question: What is the primary cause of system instability when overclocking?
questions.explanation: Overclocking increases frequency requirements, often needing higher voltages for stable operation. Insufficient voltage causes crashes, freezes, and system instability even at moderate overclocks.

questions.question: Which storage interface provides the lowest latency for enterprise applications?
questions.explanation: Intel Optane with 3D XPoint technology provides the lowest latency (sub-10 microseconds) and highest endurance, designed specifically for enterprise applications requiring extreme performance.

questions.question: What is the purpose of CPU microcode updates?
options: Fix CPU bugs and security vulnerabilities
questions.explanation: Microcode updates patch CPU bugs, security vulnerabilities (like Spectre/Meltdown), and improve stability. They're delivered through BIOS updates or OS-level patches.

questions.question: Which factor most affects SSD performance degradation over time?
questions.explanation: Write amplification (writing more data than requested) and wear leveling algorithms affect SSD longevity and performance as NAND cells wear out after repeated program/erase cycles.

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of ECC memory in professional workstations?
questions.explanation: ECC (Error-Correcting Code) memory detects and corrects single-bit errors automatically, preventing data corruption critical in professional applications like scientific computing and servers.
